spanishExample: No es justo, ¡cree en ti mismo!
englishTranslation: It’s not fair, believe in yourself!
vocabIncluded: mismo: adjective meaning "herself", "myself", etc. for emphasis (e.g. "yo misma")

spanishExample: Queremos que la mujer crea que todo está bien.
englishTranslation: We want the woman to think that everything is fine.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
crea: believe, he/she/it believe (Creer, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Queremos que pienses en lo que ella te dijo ayer.
englishTranslation: We want you to think about what she told you yesterday.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pienses: think, you think (Pensar, subjunctive, 2nd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Quieren que crea lo que me están diciendo, pero sé que no es la verdad.
englishTranslation: They want me to believe what they’re telling me, but I know it’s not the truth.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
crea: believe, I believe (Creer, subjunctive, 1st person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: ¡Créeme! Tienes que creerlo, es la verdad.
englishTranslation: Believe me! You have to believe it, it’s the truth.
vocabIncluded: creerlo: to believe it (Creer infinitive) + CONTRACTION
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¡No le creas! Sabes que pensó en eso.
englishTranslation: Don’t believe him! You know he thought about that.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
pensó: thought, he/she/it thought (Pensar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡No pienses en eso! Si lo haces, vas a tener problemas.
englishTranslation: Don't think about that! If you do it, you are going to have problems.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¡Piensa! ¿No sabes dónde lo dejaste? Creí que sabías.
englishTranslation: Think! Don’t you know where you left it? I thought you knew.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creía: believed, I believed (Creer, imperfect, 1st person)
dejaste: stopped/left/allowed, you stopped/left/allowed (Dejar, preterite, 2nd person)
dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¡Piénsalo! Yo también tengo que pensarlo.
englishTranslation: Think about it! I also have to think about it.
vocabIncluded: pensarlo: to think about it (Pensar infinitive) + CONTRACTION
piénsalo: think about it (Pensar, imperative contraction)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¡Piense! ¿No sabe dónde están?
englishTranslation: (formal) Think! Don’t you know where they are?
vocabIncluded: dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¡Piensen en lo que hicieron!
englishTranslation: Think about what you(all) did!
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: ¿Creen en esas cosas? Antes yo creía que eran verdad.
englishTranslation: Do you(all) believe in those things? Before I used to believe they were true.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creen: believe, they believe (Creer, present, 3rd person plural)
creía: believed, I believed (Creer, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Piensas en lo que pasó? Yo pienso mucho en eso.
englishTranslation: Do you think about what happened? I think a lot about that.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
pasó: passed, he/she/it passed (Pasar, preterite, 3rd person)
piensas: think, you think (Pensar, present, 2nd person)
pienso: think, I think (Pensar, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Se lo dirás por teléfono?
englishTranslation: Will you tell it to him over the phone?
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"

spanishExample: Cree que las cosas están muy bajas.
englishTranslation: He thinks the things are very low.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
cree: believes, he/she/it believes (Creer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Creemos que lo que hizo no está bien.
englishTranslation: We think that what he did isn't right.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
"lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creemos: believe, we believe (Creer, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Creo que esos bienes son suyos, pero tú no crees eso.
englishTranslation: I believe those goods are hers, but you don’t believe that.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
crees: believe, you believe (Creer, present, 2nd person)
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: De todas formas, ella creía que él ya había pensado en eso.
englishTranslation: Anyways, she believed he had already thought about that.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creía: believed , he/she/it believed (Creer, imperfect, 3rd person)
había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Él era el chico más rápido, por eso siempre era el primero.
englishTranslation: He was the fastest boy; that’s why he was always the first.

spanishExample: Él va a pensar en eso por mucho tiempo.
englishTranslation: He’s going to think about that for a long time.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Ella dice que es más baja, pero creo que son iguales.
englishTranslation: She says she’s shorter, but I think they are the same.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Esas cosas están muy altas, ¿me las puedes dar?
englishTranslation: Those things are very high; can you give them to me?
vocabIncluded: las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Está pensando en esas cosas porque vio mucho fuego en ese lugar.
englishTranslation: He is thinking about those things because he saw a lot of fire in that place.
vocabIncluded: vio: saw, he/she/it saw (Ver, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Este perro es más alto que ese.
englishTranslation: This dog is taller than that one.

spanishExample: Hace buen tiempo hoy, podemos estar cerca del agua clara.
englishTranslation: The weather is very good today; we can be near the clear water.
vocabIncluded: cerca: near (adverb often used with de)
del: "of the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: La semana pasada pensé mucho en eso y creo que estoy lista.
englishTranslation: Last week I thought a lot about that and I think I’m ready (f).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)
pensé: thought, I thought (Pensar, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Lo haremos cuando la familia piense en lo que les dijimos.
englishTranslation: We’re going to do it when the family thinks about what we told them.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
haremos: "will do/make", "we will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person plural)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
piense: think, he/she/it think (Pensar, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Lo vamos a hacer para que creas en nosotros.
englishTranslation: We are going to do it so that you believe in us.
vocabIncluded: creas: believe, you believe (Creer, subjunctive, 2nd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: No puedes estar en la cama todo el día si quieres un café.
englishTranslation: You can’t be in bed all day if you want a coffee.

spanishExample: No queremos que piensen que no queremos ir con ellos.
englishTranslation: We don't want them to think we don’t want to go with them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
piensen: think, they think (Pensar, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Nos fuimos tarde y pensamos en eso.
englishTranslation: We left late and we thought about that.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
pensamos: thought, we thought (Pensar, preterite, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Nos lo dijo y ahora pensamos en esas cosas.
englishTranslation: She told it to us and now we’re thinking about those things.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
pensamos: think, we think (Pensar, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Quieren que piense en lo que pasó esta noche.
englishTranslation: They want me to think about what happened tonight.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pasó: passed, he/she/it passed (Pasar, preterite, 3rd person)
piense: think, I think (Pensar, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Sé que pensabas en ella porque no te ha creído.
englishTranslation: I know you were thinking about her because she hasn’t believed you.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
pensabas: thought, you thought (Pensar, imperfect, 2nd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Sé que pensaste en eso ayer.
englishTranslation: I know you thought about that yesterday.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pensaste: thought, you thought (Pensar, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Siempre piensa en su hermana.
englishTranslation: He always thinks about his sister.
vocabIncluded: piensa: thinks, he/she/it thinks (Pensar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Tengo que creer que ellos no tenían el arma.
englishTranslation: I have to believe they didn’t have the weapon.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tu amigo no te creyó.
englishTranslation: Your friend didn’t believe you.
vocabIncluded: creyó: believed, he/she/it believed (Creer, preterite, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Yo pensaba en él y él pensaba en mí.
englishTranslation: I thought about him and he thought about me.
vocabIncluded: pensaba: thought, I thought (Pensar, imperfect, 1st person)
pensaba: thought, he/she/it thought (Pensar, imperfect, 3rd person)
